history.content:
CS 152 is the 'direct sequel' to the hardware portion of 61C, and requires only 61C (only offered in spring though). You could also take EECS 151 (but it requires EE16B).

=====================

EDIT:

you should definitely look into EECS151. It goes much more in depth into the 61C level of hardware and you have a project where you make an actual CPU for real with a lot of extras (61C was a gentle introduction). It's arguably a more direct sequel, since 152 is much more high level and about architecture rather than directly about hardware.

==========

If building the 61c project was your favorite thing, take the ASIC 151 lab!  The project is to actually design a processor+cache (but way more advanced than the 61c project); by the end you will have a layout that can actually be taped out (if it were a real process but still :)).  151 doesn't really require any background knowledge besides 61c, so you can go for it!

CS 152 is the 'direct sequel' to the hardware portion of 61C, and requires only 61C (only offered in spring though). You could also take EECS 151 (but it requires EE16B).

=====================

EDIT:

you should definitely look into EECS151. It goes much more in depth into the 61C level of hardware and you have a project where you make an actual CPU for real with a lot of extras (61C was a gentle introduction). It's arguably a more direct sequel, since 152 is much more high level and about architecture rather than directly about hardware.

CS 152 is the 'direct sequel' to the hardware portion of 61C, and requires only 61C (only offered in spring though). You could also take EECS 151 (but it requires EE16B).

=====================

EDIT:

While the original response is correct, you should also look into EECS151. It requires a 16B level of hardware but goes much more in depth into the 61C level of hardware and you have a project where you make an actual CPU for real with a lot of extras (61C was a gentle introduction).
CS 152 is the 'direct sequel' to the hardware portion of 61C, and requires only 61C (only offered in spring though). You could also take EECS 151 (but it requires EE16B).

children.subject: Take 16a and 16b asap. Every lab allows you to "get your hands dirty" and build something meaningful. The classes are also structured to teach things in a modeing and design focused perspective. There's a reason why they are part of the lower divs.

history.content:
I'm taking 61C right now, and I think building a RISC-V processor has definitely been my favorite CS project ever at Berkeley. I tore through it in a night. I never realized how cool hardware can be, and until now had only been considering software based classes (I haven't taken 16a or 16b yet).

My question is, where can I go to get more like this, given that I don't have the EE experience at the moment to dive into more hardware based classes. In particular, I am interested in courses where we get our hands dirty and actually make something. I understand that probably most courses like that are upper div EE, and so I will have to wait a year or more to fulfill the prereqs, but I was wondering if anyone knew of any decals/ things I could do without EE 16a/b do go deeper into computer architecture/engineering.
history.subject: More 61C Style CPU Design
